bibl.title: Letter to Dear Doctor Ferrell
Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to John A. Ferrell, January 9, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] comments extensively on a public health film on malaria.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to John A. Ferrell, January 9, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC
N. M. C.
Ferrell
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
January 9, 1922.
Dr. John A Ferrell,
Director for the United States,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Ferrell:
div1.p:
I am afraid you have sent your Scenario to the wrong man. Very
little do I know of the methods for advertising of any kind--even mal-
arial sanitation, and so little about moving pictures that I am doubt-
ful of not a few of the meanings of the titles of your pictures.

However, since you have asked what I think, here is my judgment of
it in some detail:

Scene 1: If the dark stipple is meant--as I judge it is--to simply
show the malarial regions, should not the great central plateau of Amer-
ica, west of the Missouri, be shown white? And the same, though a
smaller affair, for the Appalachians?

Scene 3: title 6: Are there 1,000,000 deaths per annum from malaria
in India?

Title 7: Does not the malaria chill in fact show as often “every
day” as “every other?” Also are not pains in the muscles--there are none
in either bones or joints--more marked during the chill than in the hot
stage of malaria? Of course you know that the fever--as shown by the ther
formermother com--goes on with the chill.

Title 9: I don't know whether you wantcount spontaneous recovery as “cured”
or not? but many cases, especially among negroes, do undergo spontaneous
recovery: Among whites I think the majority become chronic.

Scene 10: I don't think your farmer should pull out a watch. In
the first place, he wouldn't be apt to have one and in the next “sun-
time” is what he goes by. I also have plowed corn!
corn!

Scene 11: I am glad you make the doctor young. He would be far
more apt to make a blood examination than some of the old ones.

Title 15: I think I would leave this out, as you have suggested. If
you insist upon the extreme smallness of the plasmodium, the country-
man will regard it as imaginary and of no importance.
Title 21: Isn't the last e in “Anopheles” long? An-of-el-eez?
Scene 16: Is exceedingly good, as is 15 and all about the doctor.

Title 22: Shouldn't you insert after the word “female” “bites and
so carries” etc. Otherwise our countryman will console himself with
thinking that half of the mosquitoes that bite him are males any way and
won't be as afraid of them as he should be.

Title 23 to title 41: I don't know enough about making films to judge
of this. In so far as it can be done it would--to me--be extremely in-
teresting. I don't see how (Diagram 8) you can show the ookinete form-
ing or entering the mid-gut wall, (Scene 19), the stomach with oocysts
on the outside is easily shown, but not by section.
The sporozoites (Scene 20) can be shown.

Title 28: Shouldn't “about” be inserted between “After” and “twelve,”
for in cold weather the “extrinsic incubation of malaria” may take from 20
to 28 days. The bursted ooacyst scattering the sporozoites would be a
good thing to show just after Scene 20.

Title 31: Here you make the mosquito infected from the sick man fly
directly to the healthy man and, presumably, infect him. Yet you have
just stated that “it takes about twelve days” from biting before the mos-
quito becomes infective." What she really does after biting the sick
man is to go out and lay her eggs and then come back when a sufficient time
has elapsed for her to become infective and bite the well man. How to
show this, save by title, I do not know.

Title 36: Fortunately for our sick man, each new parasite does not
enter another blood cell. Few would recover if this happened suffered far many cycles A number of them fail to do this. Might in-
3.
in-
sert “tries to” after “parasite.” I like your Tallquist test.
From Title 41 to Title 47 inclusive seems to be all right.

title 53: I have no fault to find with the “will” in this, but
Heiser: Christophers and some others won't stand for it. I think the
most that is claimed for it, without controversy, a pretty strong “may”
or “generally will.”

Good down to 61: This is doubtless good too, but be sure to make
your model door shut against battens all around, especially at the bot-
tom--edge-fitting will not do. Would it be worth while to show a mos-
quito riding into the house on a door when it opens inwards? I have seen
it happen many times. Once at Darlings house at Ancon/Refered #183 U.S.P.H. Report xx

I suppose you have the whole window opening screened: the screen-
ing either tacked in or in a frame removable with difficulty, so that
the servant girl cannot possibly open it. Good screening is safe in
the hands of careful people, but both factors must be present.

Scene 46: Why not give the sanitarian a dipper upon a cane han-
dle 4 ft. long and make him really up to date? An enameled dipper, if you
like it.

Title 68: I object to the word “stagnant” if by this is meant what
generally is--water which has acquired a scum and become offensive from
standing. Anopheles never breed in this kind of water and one of the
greatest bars to mosquito control has been the belief in the innocu-
ousness of clear, potable water in freely running streams, but with
pools and eddies in them & into which grass hangs.

If you change “stagnant” to “standing” or “slightly moving” water
it will express the truth. And, of course, you know that some species
of Anopheles--as the maculatus--breeds only in swift streams, and in
the swift portions of such streams: “like trout,” Malcolm Watson says.

Mayne has athe most perfect moving picture--evidently taken infrom na-
ture--that I have ever seen--of the emergence of an Anopheles larva
4
larva
from the egg and of the imago from the pupa.

Title 70: I think “aquatic” is nigher truth than “larval.”
Oil destroys the eggs and pupae as well as the larvae. On the
other hand, poisons that kill by ingestion--as Paris green--are ef-
fective only against larvae.

Title 71: Do not quite agree with the process here given, when
the lighter coal oils are used, but it makes no difference.

Title 73: Do you mean those that act by contact--cresols? Or
do you mean to include those ingested--as Paris green and paraform?
Both would apply to Title 75 also. They can be used when oil is ineffective.

Title 75: I would add here: “where the minnows have access to
the larvae.” This is the truth and gets rid of the criticism of Nigrego &
the British entomologists.

Title 83: If there is any way of expressingstressing this--do so. Tile
drainage is, to my mind, the key to drainage for malaria.

This is rather a long criticism from a man who confessed that he
did not know much about the subject. Take this last proviso in in
considering it.

In general I am inclined to think that the Scenario gives
rather too much on the developement of the plasmodium in both the mos-
quito and the man for a popular film. That practically is from
Page 4 to Page 9 inclusive--six pages out of twenty. The essential
seems to me to be rather that the plasmodium is conveyed from the
sick man to the well by an Anopheles mosquito--a question of an
Anopheles mosquito rather than the detailed mechanism of this con-
veyance, but this is the only criticism I have to make, and I make
this with some reserve. I honestly think that the opinion of Smilist
Maxif and Coogle & Griffitts would be far more valuable on this than mine. I am
5.
am
anything but an expert on publicity methods.

Of course, the idea of a scenario for malaria is an excellent
one and this certainly shows all the facts in the case.
With kindest regards,
